explanation:
Agent A's scenario is correct for the presented project configuration. In the shown code digest_deinit is defined as a macro that expands to (void)0, therefore the statement digest_deinit(&da); becomes an executed no-op expression statement. According to MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (“Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code”), that call is dead code and thus constitutes a violation in the project configuration where the macro is (void)0.

A relevant caveat: if the project is built under other configurations where digest_deinit expands to actual cleanup code (i.e. not (void)0), then the call is not dead in those builds. MISRA Rule 2.2 is assessed against the actual project configuration in use; given the macro definition shown, the report is correct. Remediation options include removing the no-op call in configurations where it is empty, changing the macro use to conditional compilation so the call exists only when needed, or providing a documented deviation/justification for the intentional no-op.
